Selected Answer: B
B. Access control vestibule

An access control vestibule, also known as a mantrap, is a physical security measure designed to control access to a restricted area. It typically consists of an enclosed space with two sets of interlocking doors. The inner set of doors will only open if the outer set is securely closed, preventing unauthorized individuals from directly entering the restricted area.

The use of an access control vestibule helps maintain a record of events because each entry or exit is typically monitored and logged. It provides a controlled and monitored environment for individuals to pass through, and any attempt to gain unauthorized access or bypass the system would trigger an alarm or be recorded for security purposes.

A remote user is experiencing issues connecting to a corporate email account on a laptop. The user clicks the internet connection icon and does not recognize the connected Wi-Fi. The help desk technician, who is troubleshooting the issue, assumes this is a rogue access point. Which of the following is the first action the technician should take?

choices.B: Launch the browser to see if it redirects to an unknown site.
choices.C: Instruct the user to disconnect the Wi-Fi.
choices.D: Instruct the user to run the installed antivirus software.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
A rogue access point is an access point installed on a network without the network owner's permission. Why is this bad? If an attacker owns the access point, they can intercept the data (e.g. PII) flowing through the network.

Selected Answer: C
The first action the technician should take is to instruct the user to disconnect the Wi-Fi . This is because rogue access points can be used to steal sensitive information from users, and it is important to prevent the user from accessing the network until the issue has been resolved. Restarting the wireless adapter or running the installed antivirus software may not be effective in this situation, as they do not address the root cause of the problem . Launching the browser to see if it redirects to an unknown site may also not be helpful, as it does not provide any information about the Wi-Fi connection itself .
